title: Shiitake Mushroom
description: A popular edible mushroom with a rich, savory flavor, originally from East Asia but now cultivated worldwide.
habitat: Deciduous hardwood logs, especially oak, maple, and beech
color: Brown to tan cap with white to cream stem
distribution: Originally East Asia, now cultivated globally
growingConditions: Cool, moist conditions on hardwood substrates
culinaryUses: Excellent in stir-fries, soups, and grilled. Popular in Asian cuisine for its umami flavor. Can be used fresh or dried.
similarSpecies: May be confused with other brown mushrooms when young, but the distinctive shiitake aroma and growing habitat help identify.

title: Death Cap
description: An extremely dangerous mushroom responsible for most mushroom poisoning deaths worldwide.
habitat: Under oak trees and other hardwoods
color: Greenish-yellow to pale brown cap with white stem
distribution: Native to Europe, invasive in North America
growingConditions: Mycorrhizal with oak and other hardwood trees
similarSpecies: DEADLY DANGEROUS - Can be mistaken for edible mushrooms by inexperienced foragers. Has a distinctive bulbous stem base and white gills.
notes: NEVER eat any mushroom that could be confused with this species. Seek immediate medical attention if consumed.

title: Oyster Mushroom
description: Delicate mushrooms with a subtle seafood flavor that grow in shelf-like clusters.
habitat: Dead or dying hardwood trees, logs, and stumps
season: Year-round, peak in fall and winter
color: White, cream, tan, or gray caps
texture: Tender when young, tougher when mature
culinaryUses: Excellent sautéed, in soups, or grilled. Popular in vegetarian dishes as a meat substitute.
similarSpecies: Few dangerous look-alikes. Elm oyster mushrooms are similar but grow specifically on elm trees.

title: Chanterelle
description: Golden-colored wild mushrooms with a fruity aroma and delicate flavor, prized by gourmet cooks.
habitat: Mixed and coniferous forests, mycorrhizal with trees
texture: Firm, dry surface with forked ridges instead of true gills
growingConditions: Mycorrhizal relationship with conifers and hardwoods
culinaryUses: Excellent sautéed in butter, in cream sauces, or dried for later use. Pairs well with eggs and poultry.
similarSpecies: Jack O'Lantern mushrooms are poisonous look-alikes but grow on wood and have true gills that glow in the dark.
